quote: Some of them probably were.
I'm not afraid of you.
I'm glad to hear that.
Were your parents changelings, too?
I never knew my parents. I've been looking for them a long time.
My father died when I was four. I don't remember him very well. The last time I saw my mother, she was in her workroom... making pottery... But when I went to get her for midday meal... she was gone.
How did she act, when you last saw her?
Happy. She was making a vase for Mister Depnen, the baker. He really likes my mother so he always saves us the best loaves of greenbread.
Did your mother ever go anyplace before... on a trip... a vacation?
We don't go on trips.
Never?
We don't leave the valley.
Why not?
(thinks it's a dumb question) Nobody ever leaves the valley. Everything we need is right here.
I see.
My mother's never coming back, is she?
Why do you say that?
That's what grandfather told me.
(trying to comfort her) Taya, I don't know where your mother is, but I promise you... I'm going to do everything I can to find her and bring her back to you.

Okay, one more time, these are all isolinear rods. The ones with the white labels contain data relating to engineering system controls. The red labeled ones are for library and information storage. The blue ones are... ?
I'm never going to get this.
Give yourself some time. I didn't get a handle on this stuff until almost a year after I joined Starfleet. It's not like your going off to the Academy tomorrow.
What's wrong?
Nothing. It's just... why does everyone assume I'm going to go to the Academy?
You want to go... don't you?
(getting it off his chest) Not really.
Does your father know?
He wouldn't understand.
I know how you feel. You know what my dad wanted me to be? A musician.
It's true. I was going to be a cello player. He made me practice every day. I got to be pretty good.
When I was seventeen, my father even sent a recorded audition to the Aldeberan Music Academy.
What happened?
I got in. It was the happiest day of his life. I didn't know how to tell him I didn't want to go. So two days before I was due to leave, I went into town and signed up for Starfleet.
What did your dad do?

He was furious. But once he calmed down a little, he saw how much I wanted to join. Nowadays, when I go home, he introduces me as... (imitates his father, with pride) "My son, Senior Chief Specialist Miles Edward O'Brien." The point is, you've got to live your own life.
I don't want to disappoint my dad.
Your father's not a bad guy. He'll come around. Just give him time.
So what did you think?
Of your speech? I liked everything about it... except the content.
You disagree with my interpretation of the Eighth Prophecy.

"Disagree" might be a bit of an understatement. Passionately disagree is more like it. That way you have of taking a prophecy, and showing how it can mean exactly the opposite of the accepted interpretation is...
Brilliant... insightful...
Infuriating.
Maybe we'd better talk about something else.
Like what?
The Ilvian katterpod crop maybe? Or the new nature preserve in Hedrikspool Province? Or how about the standings in the Springball Championship.
You follow springball?
Religiously... if you'll pardon the expression. I even used to play a little.
Me, too. I had Chief O'Brien design a springball holosuite program.
Really? Let's go.
You want to play springball?
Why not? Unless you have a more pressing engagement?
Not that I can think of.
Good. I could use the practice.
Thank you for coming in. If I have any more questions, I'll let you know.
Please, have a seat.
I've seen people coming in and out of this place all morning. You plan on questioning the entire village?
If that's what it takes.
So, what have you found out so far?
Surprisingly little. No one seems to know anything about these disappearances.
I could've told you that. Saved you some time.
You don't hold out much hope that the missing villagers will be found, do you?
Nobody's found anyone so far.
From what I understand, you were one of the founders of this colony.
That's right. I'm the oldest one left.
This colony must be very important to you. You helped found it. You raised a family here.
I'm very proud of all we've accomplished.
Then explain something to me. This colony's undergoing a serious crisis, your daughter's among the missing, yet you hardly seem concerned.
There's nothing I can do to change things.
I wish there was. Now is there anything else, or can I go?
Are you sure you're all right?
Why wouldn't I be?
You seem to be in a great deal of pain.
What makes you say that?
I can see it in your eyes. Maybe you'd like to sit here a while and rest.
Wouldn't do much good. You see... I'm dying.
I'm... sorry.
I've had a good life... no regrets... I just wish I could see my daughter again. Now, if there are no more questions... ?
Actually, there is one thing I've been wondering about... (get's Rurigan's attention) How come no one ever leaves the village?
I haven't met a single person yet that's ever been outside this valley. Any idea why?
I suppose people here don't like to travel. After all, there's no place to go.
How can you be so sure? Have you ever left the valley?
Now that you mention it, no.

When I asked Colyus if he'd searched outside the valley for the missing people, he looked surprised, like he'd never thought of it before. I find that very peculiar. Where I come from, we'd have searched the entire countryside.
I guess he felt there was no point to it. I guarantee you those missing people aren't out there.
You're sure of that.
Absolutely.

So then Great Minra said to the evil changeling, "Well maybe you can turn into a mountain, or a Ghergher Beast, or a tornado... those are big things and big things are easy... but I bet you can't turn into something small... like a loaf of greenbread." And so the changeling said "Yes I can." and he did... and then do you know what happened?
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: The Great Minra gobbled him up.
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: How'd you know?
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: The changeling in your story wasn't very smart.
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: Could you turn into a loaf a greenbread?
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: I suppose I could.
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: Show me.
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: And let you gobble me up? I don't think so.
scene: 37   EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF YADERAN SETTLEMENT - DAY

quote: You see that tree.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Sometimes we go there to play. That's the farthest I've ever been from the village.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Wait here.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: But I want to see, too.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Please, do as I say. Lieutenant, come with me.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: I'm still not reading other lifeforms... no indications of any power source...
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Did you see that? It just vanished.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: It happened just as we passed those bushes.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Taya?
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Don't come any closer.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: But I brought you some Harrid berries.
scene: 38   EXT. CREST OF THE HILL - DAY

quote: Odo says you know what happened to the missing villagers?
I think I do. (finishes tinkering with reactor) It's a little complicated to explain. It'd probably be easier if I showed you. May I have your coat?
My coat?
Please.
Now step back.
I'm waiting.
This may take a minute. I don't want to make any mistakes.
That was my favorite coat.
Please, stay where you are.
Are you saying somebody used our reactor to transport the victims away?
No. It's not a transporter. It's a holographic projector. It creates an Omicron particle field and then manipulates the field to form physical objects... like your jacket.
What does this have to do with the missing people?
(breaking it to him gently) The people are made of Omicron particles, too.
You mean they're holograms.
I'm afraid so.
The component that controls the particle field is breaking down. That's why people are disappearing.
That's ridiculous. Some of the victims were my friends. One of them was my nephew.
If I'm right, everyone and everything in this village is a holographic projection.
And I thought I was desperate to find an answer.
Listen to me, Colyus. I know this is difficult to accept...
It's going to take more than a vanishing jacket to make me believe that I'm some kind of hologram.
I'd be skeptical too if I were you. But we do have further proof.
What kind of proof?
The holographic field ends just outside this valley. Earlier today, Taya tried to reach past the edge... and her arm disappeared.
Is she all right?
She's fine. Her arm rematerialized once she pulled it back inside.
Where exactly did this happen?
We could show you, if you'd like.
I think you'd better.
How's your shoulder?
Still a little sore.
Maybe we should have Doctor Bashir look at it?
I'll be okay. It's only a sprain.
I'm sorry.
Don't apologize. I should have seen it coming. Where did you learn to play like that?
My brothers and I used to play at the Singha Refugee Camp. There wasn't much else to do.
I was at Relliketh.
And now... here we are.
That was delicious.
Thank the replicators.
Here, let me help.
That's not necessary. Your shoulder...
Never felt better.
Maybe I could use some help after all.
I'll have to remember to thank Prylar Rhit for inviting you here.
You better tell him soon. Prylar Rhit is going to be returning to Bajor. It appears he fancies himself something of a Dabo player.
Really?
He's run up a sizable gambling debt. It's caused quite a scandal in the Vedek Assembly.
Let me get this straight. The man who invited you to the station, owes money... to Quark.
Who?
The little troll who runs the Dabo tables.
I have to go.
Why?
I need to talk to Prylar Rhit. I think I know the real reason he invited you here.
I don't believe it... I'm not a hologram... Listen to Colyus... We're alive... This isn't going to bring anyone back... Let him talk...
Please. Everyone calm down. We have to make a decision.
Colyus, you should be out looking for my wife and all the others who are missing.
Not wasting time listening to these strangers and their lies.
You all witnessed what happened when they brought us to the edge of the field. Merruk, we both saw your hand disappear.
It could've been a trick.
It wasn't a trick.
Then how come we never learned about this before.
Because none of you ever tried to leave the valley.
It's possible that we were programmed not to leave, so we wouldn't learn the truth.
We have to shut down the system. If we don't fix it soon, the whole village will disappear.
You don't know for certain...
Do you want to take that risk?
If we're not real, then it really doesn't matter whether the village disappears or not.
It matters to me. (playing his best card) Dax, you said that if you can fix the machine, you might be able to bring the missing people back?
We hope so.
I could see my mother again.
We've all lost someone. I say it's worth a try.
What if you turn off the projector, and you can't get it back on?
Then this village will cease to exist. But the system's only a few months away from complete failure. At least this way, we have a chance to save you.
Grandfather, please let her try.
Rurigan, what do you think?
We can't go on like this. I guess we should let her shut it down.
Any objections.
Then it's settled.
I can't wait to see my mother.
Your face isn't so scary... once you get used to it.
Thank you.
All right. Here we go.
Don't look so surprised, Lieutenant. I'm as real as you are.
I was happy living on Yadera Prime. Until the Dominion took over. And changed our whole way of life...

I woke up one day and realized I didn't belong there anymore. So I came here and used a holo-generator to recreate everything that I'd lost. I've lived here in my village for thirty years. I've watched its people marry, have children, grow old... Sometimes, I even forgot they were holograms. But now it's over.
(putting it all behind him) I'd appreciate it if you'd take me back to Yadera Prime.
But what about the villagers? What about your granddaughter?
What granddaughter? You mean Taya? She's not real.
Technically, I suppose you're right. Maybe by our definition, Taya's not real.

Her memories are stored in a computer and her body's made up of Omicron particles. But who's to say that our definition of life is the only valid one. I'm sure if you asked her, she'd say she was real. She thinks, she feels...
She only seems to... It's all an illusion, an illusion that I created.
You said you created this village thirty years ago. Taya's only ten.
I designed the program so that the villagers could have children if they wanted to.
Then Taya's personality is a combination of her parent's personalities.
Just like a real child. You had nothing to do with it.
But she's still a hologram.
Maybe, but I saw the way you held her hand when she was sad... how you comforted her when she was frightened.
I didn't want to see her get hurt.
If she's not real, what does it matter?
It matters to me.
Why should it matter to you if a hologram cries?
Because... I love her.
And she loves you.
Don't you see... she's real to you. And she's real to me, too. They're all real. And you can't turn your back on them now.
Jake... how was work?
Okay.
It's kind of fun working with Chief O'Brien. Of course, it'd be better if I knew what I was doing.
You'll get there.
I guess so.
I'm glad you decided to stick with it.
Yeah. (almost blurting it out) Dad, I don't want to join Starfleet.
Since when?
Since forever. Starfleet is too much... like you. And I have to find what's me. Does that make any sense?
Perfect sense.
It does?
It's your life, Jake. You have to choose your own way. There's only one thing I want from you.
Find something you love... and do it the best you can...
I'll try.
Good. Then you'll make your old man proud.
I better go study. I'm still trying to figure out those isolinear rods.
Hello, Quark.
Major... to what do I owe this unexpected pleasure.
Just thought I'd let you know... we caught your cousin trying to slip back onto the station. And guess what we confiscated from him... Bone-carvings... stolen from a museum on Cardassia Five.
I always knew Kono was no good.
I'm only sorry we didn't catch the two of you together.
Life is full of disappointments.
Oh, by the way... Prylar Rhit tells me you "encouraged" him to invite Bareil onto the station.
Is that a crime?
Not at all... I just wanted to say thanks. I found him very... diverting.
Not diverting enough.
All right, nothing to do now but reactivate the system and see what happens.
Lieutenant... wait. I have a favor to ask. If it works, please don't tell any of the others that I'm... not like them. I don't want to be treated any differently than before.
Of course.
Mother!
You did it.
We upgraded the system's memory core and realigned the field generator. You shouldn't have to worry about anyone disappearing now.
We just have to get used to the fact that we're holograms.
We're alive and we have our families back. That's the only thing that counts.
I wonder who created all this?
Whoever it was did a fine job.
They did. Didn't they?
It was good working with you, Odo. Next time you're on this side of the galaxy... I hope you come see us. We don't get many visitors.
I would like that.
Odo, my mother's back.
I'm glad.
You're leaving.
I'm afraid so.
I'll miss you.
I'll miss you, too.
Thank you for bringing my mother back. I hope you find your parents, too.
Thank you, Taya. So do I.
Taya.
Computer, two to beam up.
A little lower... lower... lower...
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: How's that?
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Mmmm.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I hope this taught you a lesson.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: What's that?
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Never play springball against a changeling.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Just for that, next time I'm not going to let you win a single game.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Then you'd better work on your backhand.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Right now, all I want to do is sleep for two or three... days.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Go right ahead, I should be back by the time you wake up.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Back? From where?
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I received a coded message from Gul Russol this morning.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Gul Russol? I thought he was executed when Cardassia joined the Dominion.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: So did I. But apparently, we were wrong. The message says he wants to meet with me.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Why?
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I don't know, but he's my most reliable Cardassian informant.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: You mean "was." What if Russol is dead and this is a trap?
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I've thought about that, but I have to be sure myself. I owe him that much.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: You want me to go with you?
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Russol insists I come alone.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Don't worry, Nerys. I'll be careful.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Who's worried? This gives me more time to work on my backhand.
scene: 1    INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Chief -- how much longer is the Promenade going to be closed? My bar is empty, my waiters are bored and I'm losing money.
Leave me alone, Quark -- or I'll feed you to one of these plasma conductors.
Are you threatening me?
We're working as fast as we can.
As spokesman of the Promenade Merchant's Association, I'm going to file an official protest with Captain Sisko.
Put it in writing, Quark.
I'll go find a PADD.
So how much longer, Chief?
We should be done here by the end of the day.
I'm not talking about the Promenade -- I'm talking about the Defiant. When are you going to get the gravity net repaired? The last time I stepped onto the bridge, I felt ten kilos heavier.
I'm afraid it's going to take some time, sir.
How much time?
About three weeks. The graviton stabilizer has to be replaced.
You have three days. The Defiant's going back out on patrol, and I don't want my crew getting queasy because the gravity keeps fluctuating.
But, sir -- the sector quartermaster said it's going to take him three weeks to get us a new stabilizer.
That's your problem, Chief. I'm leaving for a conference on Bajor and I want the stabilizer replaced by the time I get back. Do I make myself clear?
Yes, sir.
I don't want to sound negative, but I don't see how you can have the Defiant ready in three days.
Neither do I...
This quartermaster you've been dealing with -- what's his name?
Chief... (has to think for a beat) ...Willoughby.
I mean his first name.
(failing to see the relevance) I don't know...
Is he married?
Married? What does that have to do with getting a graviton stabilizer?
Everything. Chief Willoughby must get hundreds of supply requisitions every day. He can't possibly fill them all. So he puts everyone on a waiting list.
I know how he feels. I have to do the same thing.

The secret is getting him to put you at the top of that list. And the best way to do that is to form a relationship with him -- get to know the name of his wife, his children, find out what he likes to eat...
I don't have time to "form a relationship" with Willoughby.
I do. I can get you that stabilizer, Chief.
In three days?
Leave everything to me.
All right, just don't do anything I wouldn't do.
Chief, I can't operate under those kinds of restrictions.
At least promise me you won't do anything to get us court martialed.
I'll try.
Nog!
Just kidding, Chief.
Russol? Russol...
I'm afraid he couldn't be here.
Weyoun...
Founder... it is an honor to stand in your presence once again.
Where's Gul Russol?
I'm afraid the Cardassian Central Command had him put to death almost a year ago. I regret having to deceive you, but it was the only way I could think of to get you here.
(looking around the cavern) Well, I'm here. What do you want?
(tilts his head deferentially) To serve you. I no longer consider myself a member of the Dominion.
You're defecting?
Do with me as you wish. I place my fate entirely in your hands.
You don't believe me, do you?
I believe Gul Russol is dead. You say you're defecting from the Dominion. Why?
Founder... please --
I've told you before -- I'm not a Founder.
As you wish... ... Odo. I'll tell you everything you want to know -- but first, we really should get aboard your runabout. The Jem'Hadar are already hunting for me and if I'm found...
You haven't answered my question. Why did you decide to defect?
I realized my place is with you.
You can do better than that.
Then let's just say I left Cardassia because my life was in danger.
From whom?
Everyone.
Aren't you being a little paranoid?
Of course I'm paranoid -- everyone's trying to kill me.
Why?
Because this war with the Federation was supposed to have been won months ago.
Things don't always turn out as planned.
Quite true. And when things go wrong, someone has to take the blame. And this time, it's me. (looking over his shoulder) Now we really should be going...
Think about it, Odo. The information I possess could help the Federation win this war.
And you're willing to share that information.
All you have to do is ask.
We've heard rumors that the Dominion has established a new Ketracel White storage facility somewhere in Sector Five-Zero- Seven.
The facility is located in the Pelosa system. I can supply you with the exact coordinates.
(tapping his combadge) Odo to the Rio Grande. Two to beam up.
Sit here -- where I can keep an eye on you.
If it makes you feel better. But you should know I would never harm a god.
I'm not a god -- I'm a security officer. And as far as I'm concerned, you're just another prisoner.
You have no idea how much it hurts me to hear you say that.
I spoke to Edgar.
Edgar who?
Your new best friend, Chief Edgar Willoughby. He wanted me to thank you for that bottle of Gamzian wine you sent him.
I didn't send him any wine.
I took the liberty of sending it for you. By the way, his wife's name is Cynthia. They have a daughter, Melissa, age eight and a son, Edgar Junior. Age five.
You got the stabilizer?
Not quite.
What do you mean, "not quite?"
Unfortunately, he's out of stabilizers and he won't be getting a new shipment for another week.
That's it, then -- I'm doomed.
Not necessarily. Eddie told me the USS Sentinel has an extra stabilizer.
What makes you think they're going to give it to us?
I didn't say they were going to give it to us. But they might be willing to trade for it.
Trade what?
Depends on what they need and what we have.
I suppose it doesn't hurt to try. Just remember to use discretion.
Rule of Acquisition one sixty- eight: "Whisper your way to success."
Words to live by.
Oh, Chief, one more thing --
I need your authorization code.
What for?
The shipping orders.
Why don't you just bring them to me and I'll authorize them?
I just thought it would save time. When did you say the captain was going to be back?
Stop looking so worried, Chief. I've got it all under control.
I sure hope so...
I wish you'd stop doing that.
Doing what?
Staring at me.
Was I? I didn't mean to.
You've been doing it for the past ten hours.
I'm sorry. It's just such an honor to be sitting here with a --
-- security officer.
We're being hailed.
Don't respond.
It's a Cardassian transmission.
Scramble the com frequencies so they can't lock onto us.
I'm trying...
Founder. It's an honor to speak with you once again.
You look surprised to see me, Odo.
I'm well aware that all Vortas are clones. But I'm not sure the universe is ready for two Weyouns...
I couldn't agree more.
So which of you is the Weyoun I've had the misfortune of dealing with over the past few years?
Actually, neither of us.
That was Weyoun Five. Our illustrious predecessor was killed a month ago.
And I had the honor of replacing him.
What a sad day that was for the Dominion. Weyoun Five was a great man. A true patriot. His death in a transporter "accident" was most unfortunate.
And still under investigation.
A very thorough investigation that has found no evidence of foul play.
Interesting... (sorting it out, to WV-Six) So if you're Weyoun Six... ... you must be Seven.
Clones... keeping track of them is a full time job.
Why were you activated if... ... he's still alive?
Normally, I wouldn't have been. But when a clone is found to be defective...
I'm not defective!
Of course you are. What other explanation can there be for your behavior? Leaving your post... defecting to the enemy.
Are you calling Odo -- your enemy?
Absolutely not. I was referring to the Federation -- -- as you're well aware.
Enough bickering. (to Weyoun, re: WV- Six) Order him to trigger his implant.
I was getting to that.
What implant?
Like all Vorta, I have a termination implant in my brain stem.
Prove your loyalty to the Founders. Activate it.
The only Founder I'm loyal to is Odo -- and he wants me alive.
I told you it was a waste of time to try to reason with him. You're a dead man whether you activate that implant or not. That ship will never make it back to Deep Space Nine.
Founder, there's no need for you to be involved in this petty dispute. If you'll just hold your position until one of our ships can reach you...
I have no intention of releasing my prisoner to you.
If you don't, I can't be responsible for the consequences.
It's an empty threat. He wouldn't dare harm a Founder.
Maybe he won't, but I will. Think it over, Shape-shifter. One of our attack ships is on the way.
Forgive me, Odo... I should've told you the truth about myself.
It's not too late to start. Why did you defect?

It's simple really... from the moment I was activated, I felt the war was... wrong. Don't misunderstand me, I still worship the Founders, but I believe their obsession with conquering the Alpha Quadrant is misguided. It's time they learned to live in peace with the Solids. (a painful admission) I know it's not my place to question the Founders. Maybe Weyoun Seven is right -- I am defective.
On the contrary, what you're saying about the war... about the Founders -- makes perfect sense.
I want to thank you, Odo way you stood up for me... protected me...
I wouldn't let it go to your head -- I'd do the same for any prisoner.
Of course you would, you're a god.
To think that a Weyoun could be capable of such treachery.
I knew there was something wrong with him from the moment we met. He lacked your appetite for cruelty.

He's a disgrace to me and all Vorta. Though, I suppose, he's not entirely to blame for his behavior. The Vorta cloning process is a very delicate one.. every once in a while a clone is found to be... defective. It's never happened to a Weyoun before, but it does happen. And speaking of treachery... there is still the little matter of the death of Weyoun Five.
You really believe I had something to do with that?
You were supposed to be on that transporter pad with him.
I was called away... an urgent meeting with the Central Command.
How convenient.
I've always been... lucky.
You sure I can't interest you in a glass of kanar?
I'm afraid our problems won't wash away quite that easily.
I don't see what you're so concerned about... Odo can't hope to outrun a Jem'Hadar attack ship.
But what if he refuses to hand over his prisoner?
Then he'll die.
He will not. We can't kill a Founder. I forbid it.

Unless we stop them, Odo is going to take your predecessor back to the Federation where he will undoubtedly tell them all he knows... all you know... about our strategic operations. You realize what that means, don't you?
It means we could lose the war...

That's right. And I will not allow that to happen. Cardassia has risked too much... suffered too much. I will not stand by and watch all our plans... all our dreams for the future, end in defeat just to spare the life of one Shape-shifter.
I don't believe the Jem'Hadar would fire on Odo, even if they were ordered to...
They don't need to know he's on board. You can simply order them to destroy the runabout.
I suppose it might work... (then a alarming thought) But if the Founders ever found out that we were responsible for Odo's death...
Who's going to tell them?
(trying to convince himself) Odo doesn't even consider himself a Founder.
Then we agree. The runabout must be destroyed.
Excellent.
Now, I really think you should try some kanar...
Morning, lieutenant.
I'd make myself scarce if I were you.
Why?
Chief!
In here. Now.
I tried to warn you.
You mind explaining this?
Where's the captain's desk?
You mean you don't know?
This is your authorization code, isn't it?
(putting it together) Nog...
What about him?
He must've traded the captain's desk for the graviton stabilizer.
Excuse me?
Don't worry, colonel. I'll get the desk back --
You're damn right you will. The captain returns from Bajor in two days. And when he does, I want his desk sitting right here where it belongs.
So do I.
Don't worry, Chief. I didn't give away the captain's desk. I loaned it to someone.
Who?
Al Lorenzo.
Who's Al Lorenzo?
The chief of operations on Decos Prime.
What does he want with the captain's desk?
He wants to take a picture of it.
Why?
He likes to collect holophotos of himself sitting behind the desks of famous Starfleet captains. Usually he just sneaks into their offices. But with the war on, it's hard for him to get away.
Makes sense.
He has quite a photo collection -- Captain DeSoto's desk, Captain Picard's --
Okay. Fine. So once he gets the picture, he's going to send us the stabilizer.
No, he's giving us an induction modulator.
But we don't need an induction modulator.
The USS Musashi does.
(thinks he understands) Ah, and the Musashi's giving us the stabilizer.
No, they're giving us a phaser emitter.
But we don't need a phaser emitter.
I know, but the Sentinel does. And they have the extra stabilizer.
And you think they'll be willing to give it up for the phaser emitter?
That's the rumor.
Rumor? You've made all of these deals based on a rumor?
From a very reliable source.
But what if it doesn't turn out to be true?
You have to have faith, Chief.
In a rumor.
No, in the Great Material Continuum.
Who are they?
It's not a "they" -- it's the force that binds the universe together.
I must have missed that class at Engineering School.
On Ferenginar, we learn about the Continuum while we still have our first set of ears.
This is no time for Ferengi fairy tales.

The Continuum is real. You see, there are millions upon millions of worlds in the universe. Each filled with too much of one thing and not enough of another. The Great Continuum flows through them all like a mighty river, from "have" to "want" and back again. And if we navigate the Continuum with skill and grace, our ship will be filled with everything our hearts desire.
Right now, I'll settle for a stabilizer and the captain's desk.
(a simple statement of fact) The river will provide.
If it doesn't sink us, first.
I think I was... dreaming.
Sounded more like you were having a nightmare.

I was on Earth... at Starfleet Headquarters. I was supposed to report for my debriefing, but I couldn't find the right office. I kept calling your name, but you didn't answer... then suddenly, I was being chased by some Jem'Hadar -- or were they Klingons? Silly, isn't it?
Not at all. It's not easy to turn your back on your own people. Believe me, I know.
Odo, do you think Starfleet would allow you to conduct my debriefing?
Possibly.
That would make it so much easier.
What is it?
Trouble.
I can't believe they're firing on us.
Trust me, they are.
But the Jem'Hadar would never obey an order to harm a Founder.
Maybe they finally got it through their heads that I'm not a Founder.
Or they don't know who they're firing at... We've got to let them know you're on board.
I can't get through -- they're jamming all the frequencies.
They've been ordered not to communicate with us.
Damar said he was determined to stop us from reaching the station.
See if you can get above them.
(not sure if he trusts him) Why?
I'll explain later -- just do it!
Now what?
Lock phasers on their dorsal field junction -- -- their shields are weakest there.
Congratulations. You just saved our lives.
And murdered loyal servants of the Dominion. May the Founders forgive me.
Has it ever occurred to you that you believe the Founders are gods because that's what they want you to believe? That they built that into your genetic code?
Of course they did. That's what gods do. After all, why be a god if there's no one to worship you? I'm hungry. Is it all right if I get something from the replicator?
Go right ahead.
Rom, where's Nog?
I don't know, Chief. Nog left the station a couple of hours ago in a runabout.
Who gave him permission to use a runabout?
You did.
I never should've given him my authorization code. Did he say when he'd be back?
Not to me.
How could he do this to me? How could he leave me adrift, mid- river without a paddle?
What river would that be?
You know, the Great Material Continuum.
Oh. That river. It can be very treacherous.
Tell me about it. I suppose the good news is that with Nog gone, nothing else will go missing...
Where are my cases of bloodwine?!
I don't know, General. But I promise you I will find out.
I don't understand it. How could a runabout destroy a Jem'Hadar fighter?
Isn't it obvious? My predecessor must've helped Odo get past the ship's defenses.
Then how do we stop them?
How else? We send more ships. A whole squadron, if necessary. From our base at Olmerak.
Consider it done.
Remember to tell them to fire on sight.
Fire at whom?
Founder... how can I serve you?
By answering my question.
We've spotted a Federation runabout spying on our base in the Olmerak system.
Surely one ship shouldn't be much of a threat...
We'll have it destroyed within the hour.
(to the Female Shape-shifter) Are you feeling all right?
Why do you ask?
Your face...
I'm fine. But from now on, I want the temperature in these rooms lowered by fifteen degrees. I don't share the Cardassians' love of heat.
Nor do I. Lower the temperature.
(to the Female Shape-shifter) As you wish.
(to the Female Shape-shifter, solicitous) Is there anything else I can do for you?
Have you located Weyoun Six?
It's only a matter of time.
So you keep saying.
I assure you, Founder. He will be dealt with.
That was close. If she even suspected Odo was our target...
Did you notice her face? How parched it looked?
You heard her -- these rooms are too hot.
I wonder... I'm telling you she's not well.
She's not the Founder you should be worried about. Now contact Olmerak and order those ships to intercept the runabout.
That was filling.
I would hope so. You sampled the Replicator's entire menu.
I enjoyed the different... textures.
You mean tastes, don't you?
Not at all. The Vorta sense of taste is quite limited. About the only foods we really enjoy are kava nuts and rippleberries.
I take it this is also a result of your genetic programming?
It's the Founders' way of making sure we remember our past. You must know the story of how the Founders created the Vorta...
No, but I have a feeling you're going to tell me all about it.
The Vorta used to be very different from what we are today. We were forest dwellers. Small, timid, ape-like creatures living in hollowed-out trees.
Eating nuts and berries.
And living in fear of the many predators that hunted us for food. One day, a wounded changeling came stumbling through the forest fleeing a mob of angry "solids."
Why were they chasing him?
Does it matter? Solids have always feared and distrusted Shape-shifters, you know that.

A family of Vorta hid the changeling from his pursuers. And in return for saving his life, the changeling promised the Vorta that one day, they would be transformed into powerful beings. That we would become an important part of a great new empire that would stretch across the Galaxy.
And the changeling kept his word.
That's right. Imagine, Odo, my people were once little more than apes, and look at us now -- look at what you've done for us.
If the story were true, it would at least prove that my people are capable of kindness and generosity.
You care about your people very much, don't you, Odo? In spite of all that's happened between you.
Maybe I do, but that doesn't change the fact that they're responsible for a war that's killed millions.
Odo... there's something you need to know.
A sickness has spread throughout the Great Link. The Founders... are dying.

I was summoned to a meeting by the female changeling -- she wanted to discuss troop deployments with me. Suddenly, her hands began to... shrivel. It only lasted a second or two... but over the last few weeks, it's happened a number of times. It's like she's... withering.
And you're sure the other changelings have also been infected?
She said the entire Link is suffering from the disease.
Everyone but me.
If they're unable to find a cure, you'll be the last of your kind.
Why didn't you tell me this earlier?
Because I knew how much it would hurt you. I'm sorry to bring you such sad news.
But at least you're not infected. The Dominion will survive.
Meaning what?

Think about it... you have an opportunity to rectify the mistakes your people have made. To build a new Dominion based on cooperation, not conquest; on peace, not war... a new order under your leadership.
And what's your role going to be in this "new order?"
Whatever you want it to be. I wish only to serve you.
All right, then maybe you can start by telling me how one runabout is going to survive an assault by four Jem'Hadar ships.
I'm sure you'll think of something.
There's a Kuiper Belt, not far from here. We might be able to hide among the comet fragments.
But we don't have much time. They're closing fast.
These comet fragments are nothing but huge chunks of ice. The Jem'Hadar will have no trouble finding us.
Not if we become the ice...
What do you mean?
With the power off and the runabout in thermal contact with the ice, we won't generate enough of an energy signature for their sensors to read.
We "become" the ice. Only a god would think of such a thing.
(ignoring the compliment) Let's hope the Jem'Hadar give up their search before we freeze to death.
My faith will keep me warm.
Perhaps. But an hour from now, you may want to trade in that faith for a thermal blanket.
What do you think?
It's white.
I know it's white -- I'm going to paint it.
It's the wrong shape... the wrong height... the wrong width... other than that, it's perfect.
The Captain will never suspect you switched desks on him.
I need help, Julian -- not sarcasm.
I'm afraid the only person who can help you is Nog.
Maybe he isn't coming back. Maybe he decided to make a run for it.
That's not the captain's desk.
He's going to paint it.
Get it out of here.
Can I help you, General?
No...
But he can.
Bloodwine?
Sixteen cases, sent to me by my wife. Now, where are they?
How should I know?
You authorized their removal.
That is your authorization code, isn't it?
Nog...
Chief, I want that bloodwine back here by tomorrow. Understood?
Odo, when you said you were cutting power to all systems... did that include life support?
I'm afraid so.
That explains it.
Explains what?
Why I'm having trouble breathing.
We should have enough air left for another three hours.
Of course, by then we'll have probably frozen to death.
But you can't die. You have to survive to rebuild the Dominion --
They found us --
What do we do now?
We can't stay here...
You're not going to try to outrun those ships, are you?
What choice do we have?
We're on fire.
There's an extinguisher right behind you.
What are you waiting for?
I live only to serve you.
What are you doing?
Why'd you activate the com system?
All right, you can call off those ships now.
Why should I?
Because you don't need them anymore.
I'm glad to see you've come to your senses.
What've you done?
I've saved your life... and the Dominion's as well.
He's activated his termination implant and proved himself to be a worthy Vorta at last.
I obey the Founders in all things. Now call off those ships!
We don't know what he told Odo. He may have revealed important tactical --
That's a risk we'll just have to take.
I've ordered the Jem'Hadar to break off their attack. I see your runabout has suffered some battle damage. Will you require any further assistance?
I think you've done enough.
I sincerely regret any inconvenience we may have caused you, Odo. Please have a safe and pleasant journey back to Deep Space Nine.
They say voluntary termination is quick and painless... I'm afraid it's not true...
I'll get you a pain-suppressor.
That won't be necessary... but there is one thing you can do for me.
What's that?
Give me your blessing.
I can't...
Please, Odo... tell me that I haven't failed... that I've served you well.
You have. And for that, you have my gratitude...
... and my blessing.
Miles, the captain's back.
I know. He just called for me.
Good luck.
Thanks, Julian.
Chief.
Captain -- your desk...
It looks nice, doesn't it? I came in this morning to find Ensign Nog polishing it.
It was looking a little dull.
Here's the maintenance request from the Gettysberg. It should be docking later today.
That'll be all, Chief.
Yes, sir.
Oh, about the stabilizer...
Sir, I can explain...
Don't bother... Nog told me you were able to get hold of one this morning.
I was?
I mean -- I was.
How long before you can have it on-line?
About eight hours.
I intend to take the Defiant out on patrol in two.
Two it is, sir.
I don't know how you did it, Nog...
I never lost faith in the Great Material Continuum.
It's like you said -- the river will provide.
Chief!
The waters just got choppy again...
I wanted you to have this. Consider it an apology.
You found the bloodwine.
Not exactly. Ensign Nog returned from his trip with sixteen cases of twenty-three-oh-nine. A very good year.
An even better vintage than the one my wife sent me.
I'm glad you approve.
And remember, anytime you're shopping for wines or spirits -- my cousin Gant is the man to see.
We'll keep that in mind.
Your cousin Gant?
Just another sailor on the Great River...
By the way, Gant mentioned that he's got ten cases of Saurian Brandy. It's the captain's favorite, you know.
Level Five.
What's he want for them... ?
I don't think I'll ever forget the look on his face when he died. He seemed so... content.
The last thing he saw was one of his gods smiling at him. If you ask me, he was a lucky man.
Nerys, please.

No, listen to me. I know, to Starfleet the Prophets are nothing more than wormhole aliens. To me, they're gods. I can't prove it, but then again, I don't need to. My faith in them is enough. Just like Weyoun's faith in you was enough for him.
Now it appears the Vorta may have to learn to get along without their gods.
I'm sorry. You're worried about your people.
The changelings are dying and I can't help them. They're the enemy.
A very dangerous enemy -- now more than ever, because they're desperate. I know this isn't easy for you, but you have to remember that they started this war -- not you.
That's true... but I know now that which ever side wins, one thing is certain. I'm going to lose.
Computer, download file to PADD... (checking its serial number) F-seven.
Download complete.
You're up late.
I have a few things to finish up before I leave in the morning.
I'm presenting a paper at a medical conference.
I see. Where is it? Risa, Casperia Prime?
Casperia. How'd you guess?
Doctors always hold their conferences at sunny resorts.
Ours can be a grim profession. Don't you think we deserve a break from all the illness and death?
Don't forget to bring plenty of sunscreen.
Let me guess. You dislocated your shoulder.
Not again.
You promised me you wouldn't go kayaking again until your shoulder had a chance to heal.
I know. But I can't stay away. (trying to explain himself) It's like the river calls to me.
That's right. It's saying, "Stay away. Don't come near me. I'll only hurt you more!"
Much better.
It'll be tender for a few days so go easy on it.
Right.
If the pain starts to get any worse, Nurse Bandee can give you something.
Thanks, Julian. Have a good time on Casperia.
I'm going to a medical conference, not on a vacation.
Whatever you say.
Remember -- listen to the river... and stay away.
The time is oh-seven hundred hours.
You're joking. Computer, confirm time.
The time is oh-seven-hundred hours, twenty-three seconds.
Something tells me I'm going to need a lot of raktajino today.
See you in a few days, old chum. Keep the home fires burning.
Attention, senior officers. Report to Operations immediately.
What now?
This better be quick. I have a transport to catch.
What's going on?
Internal Affairs.
What are they doing here?
They're not saying.
(trying to lighten the mood) If they'd called ahead, we could've thrown them a party.
Something tells me this isn't a social visit.
Where is the captain?
(motioning to Sisko's Office) In there.
He doesn't look very happy.
No. He doesn't.
All right, people. This is Deputy Director Sloan of Internal Affairs. He's here under the authority of the Federation Council. I expect you to give him your full cooperation.
Starfleet Intelligence has reason to believe that there's been a security breach aboard Deep Space Nine.
It appears that someone has been passing information to the Dominion.
With all due respect, I think there's been some kind of mistake.
I hope you're right, commander. I really do.
But until we determine the source, we have to follow standard containment procedures and isolate the members of the senior staff.
As of now, you're all relieved of duty and confined to quarters.
Confined to quarters?
I don't like it any more than you do.
You'll be contacted shortly. I'll be conducting interviews with each one of you. For the time being, you're not to discuss this matter amongst yourselves. Any questions?
Do you have any idea how long your investigation is going to take?
It's difficult to say, doctor. But don't worry, we've already contacted Starfleet Medical and informed them that you won't be attending your conference.
How very considerate of you.
Take them to their quarters.
Would you follow me, please.
Hot buttered scones, moba jam and red leaf tea.
What's wrong with this thing?
Come in.
Would you please come with me, doctor?
Certainly.
Where are we going?
To the wardroom. Director Sloan wants to ask you some questions.
Stand clear --
What's going on?
Nothing you need to worry about, sir.
This way.
Doctor Bashir.
Have a seat.
I'm sorry you had to miss your medical conference, but it couldn't be helped. In a case like this, I have to follow strict procedures.
Of course. I understand.
Maybe it's a blessing in disguise. The last time you tried to attend a medical conference you were taken prisoner by the Dominion.
An experience I wouldn't care to repeat.
I'm sure you wouldn't. Five weeks in a Dominion prison camp -- I can't imagine what it must've been like.
It wasn't pleasant.
I read your report. (with a hint of admiration for Bashir's fortitude) It made me ask myself how I would've held up under those conditions. I guess you never really know until you go through it.
I'm sure you would've found a way to cope. We do what we have to to survive.
I was just reading some of your case reports. Fascinating stuff. The work you did with those genetically enhanced patients? Very impressive.
Thank you.

Before you started working with them, they were described by Starfleet Medical as -- -- "alienated, uncommunicative, and hostile." You're the first doctor who managed to establish a dialogue with them.
Well, I think the fact that I'm genetically enhanced myself made them more open to accepting me.
You spoke their language.
Exactly.
I envy your profession. You make a positive impact on people's lives. You know, I considered becoming a doctor myself.
You have a good bedside manner. When I walked in here, I was half expecting to be interrogated under a bright light.
Not this time.
Well, I don't see a need to trouble you any longer. Thank you for your cooperation.
My pleasure.
Lieutenant Chandler will take you back to your quarters. I'm afraid I'm going to have to ask you to stay there until I've finished the rest of the interviews.
In that case, could you send someone to have a look at my Replicator? It isn't working.
Actually, we took them off-line.
Oh?
To prevent anyone from trying to replicate a communications device or a weapon.
All I want is some breakfast.
What would you like? I'll have it sent to your quarters right away.
Hot buttered scones, moba jam and red leaf tea.
Coming right up.
Thank you.
Doctor. One more thing.
Yes.
About those genetically enhanced patients of yours. Did Starfleet Medical ask you to work with them, or did you volunteer?
I volunteered.
I see, very good.
Yes.
Here you are, sir.
Thank God. I'm famished.
Cheers.
Enjoy.
Ugh. It's a little too early for gag'h.
I hope you like scones, Worf...
Miles? Sloan said we aren't supposed to talk to each other.
I just wanted to make sure you were all right.
I'm fine. Except I think someone's been snooping around my quarters.
Wouldn't surprise me. Has Sloan questioned you yet?
We just finished.
How did it go?
He asked me a few routine questions. It went fine.
Believe me, it's not fine. He grilled me for over two hours.
Two hours? About what?
About you.
You're joking.
I only wish I were. But every single question was about you.
I'd better go before they trace this transmission. I just wanted to warn you to watch your back.
Miles, wait. What did he want to know about me?
Just be careful. I think they're --
Come in.
Director Sloan wants to see you.
Again?
That's right.
Did you get your breakfast, doctor?
Yes, I did.
Good.
I was going over my notes from our last conversation and there are a few things I'd like you to clarify.
Oh?
Do you have a problem with that?
Not at all.
Let's go back to the time you spent with the Dominion.
I wasn't "with the Dominion." I was their prisoner.
You were held at Internment Camp Three-Seven-One?
Yes.
Barracks Six?
Correct.
And you were there five weeks?
Thirty-seven days, actually.
Are you absolutely sure?
Yes.
And General Martok was with you in Barracks Six?
That's right.
He said that the Jem'Hadar removed you from the barracks.
I complained because they cut our rations, so they put me in solitary confinement.
I see, and did you meet with anyone during that week?
I was alone.
Are you sure?
Let me think. Was I alone in solitary? Yes. I think I was.
You didn't meet with a Vorta?
No.
Or a changeling?
No.
So, you're telling me that you spent seven days in complete isolation?
Not seven. Five. Five days.
That's odd. General Martok said you were gone for seven days.
Well, he's wrong. It was five.
Why would he lie about something like that?
He's not lying.
You can't both be right.
All I'm saying is that he must've lost count of the days. He was under a lot of stress at the time.
And you weren't?
Human beings tend to be better at adapting to incarceration than Klingons.
Especially if they're genetically engineered.
Meaning what?

Let's move on to the matter of your escape from the camp. I'll quote from your own report. "We constructed a transmitter using components from the barracks' life-support system. We used it to contact our runabout and beam ourselves out of the camp." Forgive me, doctor, but that sounds a little hard to believe.
It's what happened.
Why would the Dominion leave your runabout orbiting the camp unattended?
They didn't expect us to be able to contact it.
Why not? They left you everything you needed to build a transmitter.
Isn't it more plausible that the Dominion wanted you to escape?
Why? For what reason?
So that you could start working for them.
I'm not working for them.
How can you be sure?
Excuse me?
How can you be sure that you're not working for them? Are you familiar with the term engramatic dissociation?
Vaguely.
The theory holds that if a person's mind is sufficiently disciplined, he'd be capable of compartmentalizing contradictory information -- believing one thing while doing another.

I think you possess that kind of mind. I think the Dominion saw that and decided to take advantage of it. I think they broke you and turned you to their cause, then had you suppress the memory of what happened.
You're saying I'm a Dominion spy and I don't even know it?

What could be more perfect? There's no chance of your getting caught because you don't even realize you're working for them. When they're ready to debrief you, all they have to do is trigger your memory.
That's ridiculous.

Doctor, I'm trying to help you, but I need your cooperation. I need you to tear down the walls inside your mind and dredge up a fragment of memory -- anything about your mission, your contacts. I know it's not easy, but you've got to try.

There are no memories to dredge up. I am not suffering from engramatic dissociation. I am a loyal Starfleet Officer, and I am not going to answer any more questions unless I'm formally charged and can respond with the benefit of counsel.

I've had enough of your lies, doctor. You think you're smarter than the rest of us, don't you? Smarter than the millions of brave men and women who are putting their lives on the line for the Federation. You want to do things the hard way? Fine. But I'm going to get the truth out of you. And when I'm done, I'm going to take whatever's left of you and lock it away. Guards.
Is it really necessary to drag a Starfleet Officer across the Promenade in irons?
We have our orders, sir.
Please stand aside.
We're going to get you out of this, Julian.
I'm sure it's all a mistake. Isn't it?
Where's Odo?
(enjoying Bashir's discomfort) In his quarters. We'll be handling security for the time being.
(smiles re: the manacles) Too tight?
A bit.
You'll live.
I'm glad to see you enjoy your work.
I was with the Seventh Fleet when the Dominion attacked the Tyra System. Ninety-eight of our ships were destroyed in a matter of hours. I lost a lot of friends.
I lost friends there, too.
I believe that, but yours were Jem'Hadar.
You won't be needing this anymore.
Step inside.
With all due respect captain, if you'd just wait in the Security Office, Director Sloan should be here any minute and you can discuss your request with him...
There's nothing to discuss. I want ten minutes alone with my officer, and I want them now.
Very well.
I thought you should know that Odo did some checking. Sloan had a son in Starfleet -- a transport pilot. He was killed by a Dominion patrol.
Maybe he thinks I supplied the information that helped them target his son's ship.
That's exactly what I think.
When my son's convoy dropped out of warp to rendezvous with a Klingon bird of prey, they found three Dominion attack ships waiting for them instead.
I'm sorry for your loss. But don't you think your son's death indicates a conflict of interest with your investigation?
I like to think that it gives me an added incentive to get to the truth. Now what is it you want?
I need to talk to my chief medical officer in private.
I can understand that. But security protocols require that no one speak to the prisoner without clearance from me.
Director Sloan, have you received orders from Starfleet to relieve me of command of this station?
No, I haven't.

Then as long as I'm in command, I'll see Doctor Bashir whenever I please. Furthermore, from now on I'll sit in on all interrogation sessions to make sure that his rights are observed. Do I make myself clear?
I believe so.
Well then, we'll see each other tomorrow. In the meantime, I'll leave you to your conversation.
I appreciate your help, sir.
We'll get this straightened out, I promise you.
-- let's go back a few years to the incident at Bopak Three. According to your report, you and Chief O'Brien "crash-landed" on the planet, where you then made contact with a group of Jem'Hadar.
We didn't "make contact." They captured us.
If that's the case, why didn't you attempt to escape?
We didn't have the chance.
According to Chief O'Brien, you were more interested in trying to cure the Jem'Hadar of their addiction to Ketracel White.
I'm a doctor. They were suffering from withdrawal.
They're the enemy -- genetically engineered killing machines.
They're not machines, they're sentient beings. I couldn't just stand by and watch them die.
Why? Because you felt sympathy for them -- being genetically engineered yourself?
This is irrelevant. You're talking about an incident that took place before Doctor Bashir allegedly became a Dominion agent.
It's not irrelevant, Captain. If anything, it shows that he was already sympathetic to the Dominion.
(picking up another PADD) Let's move on. Doctor, we spoke yesterday about a group of genetically enhanced patients that you brought to the station. Why, exactly, did you decide to work with them?
They'd been institutionalized most of their lives. I thought I might be able to help them assimilate into society.

A laudable goal. But what I find puzzling is the way you went about it. These misfits had been sheltered from the outside world for as long as they could remember, yet you chose to bombard them with information about the war with the Dominion. Frankly, I'm surprised it didn't scare them into deeper isolation.
I was trying to engage them--- and it worked.
Is that why you convinced Starfleet Command to give them access to classified battle plans?
Starfleet was interested in hearing our ideas on how to win the war.
How to win the war? You recommended that the Federation surrender!
We were looking for a way to save as many lives as we could. If you'd take the time to examine our findings --
Captain, you took the time to examine their findings, didn't you?
I did.
Did you agree with them?
No.
Of course not. No loyal Starfleet officer could.
I won't deny that Doctor Bashir has made some... (choosing his words carefully) -- questionable decisions in his career, but you're a long way from convincing me he's a traitor.
So far, your case is based on circumstantial evidence and speculation.
What other kind of case can I make against a man who's covered his tracks so well?
That's a circular argument and you know it.

Captain, if Doctor Bashir had been involved in one or two questionable incidents, I can understand how you might be able to dismiss them. But the sheer number of incidents form a pattern of behavior that can't be ignored.

I understand that you want to be loyal to a man who's served under you for so long. I understand that you're inclined to take his word over that of an outsider. But step back for a moment and think about it. This man concealed the truth about his illegal genetic enhancement for over thirty years. He lied to get his medical license. He lied to get into Starfleet. He lied to you when he came aboard this station and he's lied to you ever since.
He did eventually come forward and tell the truth.
That's right, he did. But why? What made you confess, Doctor? Was it because you realized it was your duty to be honest with your captain?
Was it because you felt guilty about having lied to him for so long?
No.
Then why did you come forward?
Because I'd been found out.
And if you hadn't been found out? Would you have come forward and told your captain the truth... ever?
I don't know.
I see.
Sloan's right about one thing, sir. I should have told you the truth about me from the beginning.
That's right. You should have. But lets put that behind us for now.
How am I supposed to defend myself against this man? No matter what I say, he either thinks I'm lying or repressing my memories.
I know you're not lying, Julian.
